questions.text: Which part of the body is not drained by the right lymphatic duct?

options.label: A
options.text: Right side of the head and neck

questions.text: Which of the following structures is the mediastinal surface of the right lung not related to?
questions.explanation:
Right lung

Left lung

1. Right atrium (Option A)

1. Left ventricle, left auricle, infundibulum and adjoining part of the right ventricle

2. A small part of the right ventricle

2. Pulmonary trunk

3. Superior vena cava

3. Arch of aorta

4. Lower part of the right brachiocephalic vein

4. Descending thoracic aorta (Option C)

5. Azygos vein (Option B)

5. Left subclavian artery

6. Esophagus (Option D)

6. Thoracic duct

7. Inferior vena cava

7. Oesophagus

8. Trachea

8. Left brachiocephalic vein

9. Right vagus nerve

9. Left vagus nerve

10. Right phrenic nerve

10. Left phrenic nerve
 

11. Left recurrent laryngeal nerve

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient is admitted to the hospital after undergoing elective surgery. Post-anesthesia, he is found to be unconscious and placed in a supine position for monitoring. The healthcare team is concerned about the risk of aspiration due to his current state. Which location is most likely to collect aspirated material in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Anterior Basal BPS of the right lower lobe

options.label: B
options.text: Posterior BPS of the right upper lobe

options.label: C
options.text: Apical Basal BPS of the right lower lobe

options.label: D
options.text: Lateral BPS of the right middle lobe

questions.correct_answer: C. Apical Basal BPS of the right lower lobe

questions.text: A 60-year-old female undergoes right lower lobe resection for a tumor. Which statement about bronchopulmonary segments is true?

options.label: A
options.text: Each segment shares a bronchus with adjacent segments.

options.label: B
options.text: Segments are supplied by segmental arteries and share venous drainage.

options.label: C
options.text: Each segment has independent arterial and venous supplies.

options.label: D
options.text: The shape is pyramidal with the base at the hilum.

questions.correct_answer: B. Segments are supplied by segmental arteries and share venous drainage.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient presents with a persistent cough and shortness of breath. A chest X-ray shows a mass in the right lung. The attending physician is reviewing the anatomical structures relevant to potential surgical intervention. Which of the following statements about the anatomy of the right and left lungs is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: The right superior pulmonary vein is located posteriorly to the bronchus.

options.label: B
options.text: The eparterial bronchus in the right lung is found above the pulmonary artery.

options.label: C
options.text: The most superior structure of the left lung hilum is the Pulmonary vein.

options.label: D
options.text: The bronchus on the left side is shorter in length compared to the right bronchus.

questions.correct_answer: B. The eparterial bronchus in the right lung is found above the pulmonary artery.

options.label: A
options.text: A.Left main bronchus, B. Descending aorta, C. T5 vertebrae, D.Esophagus, H.Ascending aorta

options.label: B
options.text: A.Left main bronchus, B. Ascending aorta, C. T5 vertebrae, D. Esophagus, H. Descending aorta

options.label: C
options.text: A.Right main bronchus, B. Descending aorta, C. T5 vertebrae, D. Ascending aorta, H. Pulmonary artery

options.label: D
options.text: A. Right main bronchus, B. Descending aorta, C. T5 vertebrae, D. Esophagus, H. Ascending aorta

questions.correct_answer: A. A.Left main bronchus, B. Descending aorta, C. T5 vertebrae, D.Esophagus, H.Ascending aorta

questions.text: Where is pain from the mediastinal pleura typically referred?

options.label: D
options.text: In the lower back near the kidneys

questions.text: An axial CT scan of the thorax shows a slice where the aortic arch is visible, along with the trachea bifurcating into the main bronchi. At which anatomical level is this axial section most likely taken?
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ Level of the Thoracic Inlet : This is at the top of the thoracic cavity, where the trachea and esophagus enter.
  • ↳ Level of the Thoracic Inlet
  • ↳ Level of the Aortic Arch : Located around the T4-T5 vertebral level, where the aorta arches over the left main bronchus.
  • ↳ Level of the Aortic Arch
  • ↳ T4-T5
  • ↳ Level of the Carina : At the T5-T6 level, this is where the trachea bifurcates into the right and left main bronchi.
  • ↳ Level of the Carina
  • ↳ T5-T6
  • ↳ Level of the Heart : The heart is typically seen from T6 to T9 . You can identify the chambers (right atrium, left atrium, ventricles) and major vessels (aorta, pulmonary arteries).
  • ↳ Level of the Heart
  • ↳ T6 to T9
  • ↳ Level of the Diaphragm : The diaphragm typically corresponds to the T10 vertebral level, which can help in distinguishing between thoracic and abdominal structures.
  • ↳ Level of the Diaphragm
  • ↳ T10
  • ↳ Level of the Esophagus : The esophagus runs along the midline and can be seen at various levels, usually starting from the cervical region down to T10.
  • ↳ Level of the Esophagus
  • ↳ cervical region down to T10.
  • ↳ Level of the Thoracic Spine : The thoracic vertebrae can be used as references; typically, there are 12 thoracic vertebrae.
  • ↳ Level of the Thoracic Spine
  • ↳ T1-T2 (Option A): This level generally shows the upper mediastinum, including parts of the great vessels, but the aortic arch is not typically prominent.
  • ↳ T1-T2 (Option A):
  • ↳ T5-T6 (Option C): Here, the main bronchi are visible, but the aortic arch may not be well-defined.
  • ↳ T5-T6 (Option C):
  • ↳ T7-T8 (Option D): This level typically shows the lower mediastinum and may not include the aortic arch or the bifurcation of the trachea.
  • ↳ T7-T8 (Option D):

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presents with a history of progressive shortness of breath and swelling in the neck. Imaging reveals distended chest wall veins and a mediastinal mass with known metastasis. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
Which of the following structures does not make up the anterior surface (sternocostal) of the heart?
questions.explanation:
Anterior surface of heart (Sternocostal)

Posterior View of Heart (Base)
  • The anterior surface consists mainly of the right atrium and right ventricle separated by the anterior atrioventricular groove (coronary sulcus). (Option B)
  • The left auricle and left ventricle also contribute. (Option C & D)
  • The right ventricle is separated from the left ventricle by the anterior interventricular groove.
  • The left atrium is obscured by the ascending aorta and pulmonary trunk.
  • The heart creates a cardiac notch on the mediastinal surface and anterior border of the left lung causing superficial cardiac dullness
  • The base of the heart is mainly formed by the left atrium (two-thirds) and right atrium (one-third).
  • Major blood vessels like superior vena cava, ascending aorta, and pulmonary trunk attach to the base.
  • It is directed backwards and to the right, opposite the apex.
  • The base lies opposite the apex and in front of thoracic vertebrae T5–T8 when lying down, descending to T6–T9 when standing.
  • It is separated from the vertebral column by the oblique pericardial sinus, esophagus, and aorta.

questions.text: In the given CT slice, A and B respectively represent?

A 65-year-old male presents with shortness of breath and chest pain. On examination, he has a prominent sternal angle. A CT scan reveals an enlarged mediastinal lymph node at the level of the tracheal bifurcation. Which of the following anatomical structures is most likely to be found at the same level as the bifurcation of the trachea?

options.label: B
options.text: Junction of the azygos vein and superior vena cava

options.label: D
options.text: Superior border of the aortic arch

questions.correct_answer: B. Junction of the azygos vein and superior vena cava
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ The sternal angle ( angle of Louis) is a palpable, transverse ridge on the sternum located approximately 5 cm below the suprasternal notch.
  • ↳ sternal angle
  • ↳ angle of Louis)
  • ↳ It serves as a critical anatomical landmark for various significant structures and anatomical events. These include: The second costal cartilage articulates with the sternum at this level on both sides, making it a key reference point for counting ribs. It corresponds to the level of the intervertebral disc between the T4 and T5 vertebrae . A horizontal plane passing through this level divides the superior mediastinum from the inferior mediastinum . The arch of the aorta both begins and ends at this level. The trachea bifurcates into the right and left principal bronchus at this level. The pulmonary trunk divides into the right and left pulmonary arteries here. The upper border of the heart is located at this level. The azygos vein arches over the root of the right lung and empties into the superior vena cava at this level. (Option B)
  • ↳ The second costal cartilage articulates with the sternum at this level on both sides, making it a key reference point for counting ribs. It corresponds to the level of the intervertebral disc between the T4 and T5 vertebrae . A horizontal plane passing through this level divides the superior mediastinum from the inferior mediastinum . The arch of the aorta both begins and ends at this level. The trachea bifurcates into the right and left principal bronchus at this level. The pulmonary trunk divides into the right and left pulmonary arteries here. The upper border of the heart is located at this level. The azygos vein arches over the root of the right lung and empties into the superior vena cava at this level. (Option B)
  • ↳ The second costal cartilage articulates with the sternum at this level on both sides, making it a key reference point for counting ribs.
  • ↳ second costal cartilage
  • ↳ It corresponds to the level of the intervertebral disc between the T4 and T5 vertebrae . A horizontal plane passing through this level divides the superior mediastinum from the inferior mediastinum .
  • ↳ intervertebral disc between the T4 and T5 vertebrae
  • ↳ superior mediastinum
  • ↳ inferior mediastinum
  • ↳ The arch of the aorta both begins and ends at this level.
  • ↳ arch of the aorta
  • ↳ The trachea bifurcates into the right and left principal bronchus at this level.
  • ↳ trachea bifurcates
  • ↳ The pulmonary trunk divides into the right and left pulmonary arteries here.
  • ↳ pulmonary trunk
  • ↳ The upper border of the heart is located at this level.
  • ↳ upper border of the heart
  • ↳ The azygos vein arches over the root of the right lung and empties into the superior vena cava at this level. (Option B)
  • ↳ azygos vein
  • ↳ superior vena cava
  • ↳ (Option B)
  • ↳ Left atrium of the heart (Option A) lies posteriorly and is located lower than the sternal angle, around the T6-T7 vertebral level.
  • ↳ Left atrium of the heart (Option A)
  • ↳ Origin of the thoracic duct (Option C) : is in the abdomen at the cisterna chyli , at the level of the L1-L2 vertebrae, far below the level of the sternal angle.
  • ↳ Origin of the thoracic duct (Option C)
  • ↳ cisterna chyli
  • ↳ L1-L2
  • ↳ Superior border of the aortic arch (Option D) : is located slightly above the level of the sternal angle, but its lower border (or the beginning and end of the arch) aligns with the T4-T5 level.
  • ↳ Superior border of the aortic arch (Option D)

questions.text: All the following are contents of the posterior mediastinum except:
questions.explanation:
Anterior Mediastinum

Middle Mediastinum

Posterior Mediastinum
  • Lies between the sternum and the pericardium
  • Contains loose connective tissue, lymph nodes, and remnants of the thymus, sterno -pericardial ligaments.
  • Provides surgical access to the heart and great vessels
  • The broadest part of the inferior mediastinum
  • Contains the heart enclosed in the pericardial sac
  • Contains the roots of great vessels: ascending aorta, pulmonary trunk, and pulmonary veins, tracheal bifurcation and bronchi
  • Includes the phrenic nerves and cardiac plexus
  • Extends from the posterior pericardium to the vertebral column
  • Contains important structures such as:

(Option A, B, C)

  1. Descending thoracic aorta
  2. Esophagus
  3. Azygos and hemiazygos veins
  4. Thoracic duct
  5. Sympathetic trunks and splanchnic nerves
  6. Lymph nodes

questions.text: Match the following coronary arteries with the areas of the heart they predominantly supply: Coronary Arteries Supplied Areas 1) Right conus artery a) Anterior 2/3 of interventricular septum 2) Left anterior descending artery (LAD) b) Infundibulum of right ventricle 3) Left circumflex artery (LCX) c) Posterior interventricular septum 4) Posterior descending artery (PDA) d) Lateral wall of the left ventricle e) Apex of the heart
questions.explanation:
Artery

Supplied Region

Right Conus Artery (RCA)

Infundibulum of the right ventricle

Left Anterior Descending (LAD)

Anterior 2/3 of the interventricular septum

Left Circumflex Artery (LCX)

Lateral wall of the left ventricle

Posterior Descending Artery (PDA)

Posterior interventricular septum

Artery

Right Coronary Artery (RCA)

Left Coronary Artery (LCA)

Origin

Arises from the right aortic sinus.

Arises from the left aortic sinus.

Course

Moves forward between the pulmonary trunk and right auricle, descending in the right atrioventricular groove.

Passes forward between the pulmonary trunk and the left auricle, and then splits into two main branches.

Branches

Right Conus Artery:

  • Supplies the pulmonary conus (infundibulum) and the upper right ventricle.
 

Anterior Ventricular Branches:

  • 2 or 3 in number - supply the anterior surface of the right ventricle.
 

Right Marginal Artery:

  • Largest of anterior ventricular branches - runs along the right margin of the heart towards the apex.
 

Posterior Descending Artery (PDA) or the posterior interventricular artery:

  • Travels in the posterior interventricular groove, supplying the inferior wall of both ventricles and the posterior part of the interventricular septum.
  • This artery often arises from the RCA but can also originate from the LCA in some individuals.
 

Atrial Branches:

  • Supply the right atrium and contribute to the SA node in some individuals.

Left Anterior Descending Artery (LAD):

  • Travels down the anterior interventricular groove to the heart’s apex.
  • It supplies both ventricles and the anterior two-thirds of the interventricular septum.
 

Left Circumflex Artery (LCX): Circles around the left margin of the heart in the atrioventricular groove, giving off:

 
  • Left Marginal Artery: Supplies the left margin of the left ventricle.
  • Anterior and Posterior Ventricular Branches: Supply the left ventricle.
  • Atrial Branches: Supply the left atrium.
 

Lateral or diagonal artery - larger ventricular branch - may arise directly from the trunk of the left coronary artery.

  • A small left conus artery supplies the pulmonary conus.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with recurrent episodes of supraventricular tachycardia. The electrophysiologist plans to perform catheter ablation. Which of the following structures is most likely to be found at the apex of Koch's triangle?
Which of the following veins does not drain into the coronary sinus but rather drains directly into the right atrium?
Which sulcus contains major coronary arteries?
